sentence.text: Drug Label for drug brand Betapace, containing Sotalol Hydrochloride.

mmtx.phraseText: Drug Label for drug brand Betapace,
Drug Label for drug brand Betapace,

sentence.text: Sotalol is also indicated for the maintenance of normal sinus rhythm delay in time to recurrence of atrial fibrillation/atrial flutter (AFIB/AFL) in patients with symptomatic AFIB/AFL who are currently in sinus rhythm and is marketed under the brand name Betapace AF.

mmtx.phraseText: marketed under the brand name Betapace AF.

sentence.text: Betapace is not approved for the AFIB/AFL indication and should not be substituted for Betapace AF because only Betapace AF is distributed with a patient package insert that is appropriate for patients with AFIB/AFL.

Betapace (sotalol hydrochloride) is contraindicated in patients with bronchial asthma, sinus bradycardia, second and third degree AV block, unless a functioning pacemaker is present, congenital or acquired long QT syndromes, cardiogenic shock, uncontrolled congestive heart failure, and previous evidence of hypersensitivity to Betapace.
Patients in CAST I were randomized to receive placebo or individually optimized doses of encainide, flecainide, or moricizine.

As compared to placebo treatment, all three active therapies were associated with increases in short-term (14-day) mortality, and encainide and flecainide were associated with significant increases in longer-term mortality as well.

Betapace (sotalol hydrochloride) is devoid of Class I effects, and in a large (n 1,456) controlled trial in patients with a recent myocardial infarction, who did not necessarily have ventricular arrhythmias, Betapace did not produce increased mortality at doses up to 320 mg/day (see Clinical Studies ).

Like other antiarrhythmic agents, Betapace can provoke new or worsened ventricular arrhythmias in some patients, including sustained ventricular tachycardia or ventricular fibrillation, with potentially fatal consequences.

The risk of Torsade de Pointes progressively increases with prolongation of the QT interval, and is worsened also by reduction in heart rate and reduction in serum potassium (see Electrolyte Disturbances).
In patients who have congestive heart failure controlled by digitalis and/or diuretics, Betapace should be administered cautiously.
Both digitalis and sotalol slow AV conduction.
Special attention should be given to electrolyte and acid-base balance in patients experiencing severe or prolonged diarrhea or patients receiving concomitant diuretic drugs.
Hypersensitivity to catecholamines has been observed in patients withdrawn from beta-blocker therapy.

Therefore, it is prudent when discontinuing chronically administered Betapace, particularly in patients with ischemic heart disease, to carefully monitor the patient and consider the temporary use of an alternate betablocker if appropriate.

mmtx.phraseText: the temporary use of an alternate betablocker

sentence.text: It is prudent, if Betapace (sotalol hydrochloride) is to be administered, to use the smallest effective dose, so that inhibition of bronchodilation produced by endogenous or exogenous catecholamine stimulation of beta 2 receptors may be minimized.

mmtx.phraseText: exogenous catecholamine stimulation of beta 2 receptors

sentence.text: While taking beta-blockers, patients with a history of anaphylactic reaction to a variety of allergens may have a more severe reaction on repeated challenge, either accidental, diagnostic or therapeutic.

In patients with diabetes (especially labile diabetes) or with a history of episodes of spontaneous hypoglycemia, Betapace should be given with caution since beta-blockade may mask some important premonitory signs of acute hypoglycemia, e.g., tachycardia.
Betapace ( sotalol hydrochloride) is mainly eliminated via the kidneys through glomerular filtration and to a small degree by tubular secretion.

Class Ia antiarrhythmic drugs, such as disopyramide, quinidine and procainamide and other Class III drugs (e.g., amiodarone) are not recommended as concomitant therapy with Betapace, because of their potential to prolong refractoriness (see WARNINGS ).
Additive Class II effects would also be anticipated with the use of other beta-blocking agents concomitantly with Betapace.
Single and multiple doses of Betapace do not substantially affect serum digoxin levels.

Proarrhythmic events were more common in Betapace treated patients also receiving digoxin, it is not clear whether this represents an interaction or is related to the presence of CHF, a known risk factor for proarrhythmia, in the patients receiving digoxin.

mmtx.phraseText: more common in Betapace treated patients also
related to the presence of CHF,

sentence.text: Both digitalis glycosides and beta-blockers slow atrioventricular conduction and decrease heart rate.
Concomitant use can increase the risk of bradycardia.

ellipsisSentence.text: Both digitalis glycosides and beta-blockers slow atrioventricular conduction and decrease heart rate.
Both digitalis glycosides and beta-blockers slow atrioventricular conduction and decrease heart rate.

sentence.text: Betapace should be administered with caution in conjunction with calcium-blocking drugs because of possible additive effects on atrioventricular conduction or ventricular function.
Additionally, concomitant use of these drugs may have additive effects on blood pressure, possibly leading to hypotension.

ellipsisSentence.text: Betapace should be administered with caution in conjunction with calcium-blocking drugs because of possible additive effects on atrioventricular conduction or ventricular function.
Betapace should be administered with caution in conjunction with calcium-blocking drugs because of possible additive effects on atrioventricular conduction or ventricular function.
Betapace should be administered with caution in conjunction with calcium-blocking drugs because of possible additive effects on atrioventricular conduction or ventricular function.
Betapace should be administered with caution in conjunction with calcium-blocking drugs because of possible additive effects on atrioventricular conduction or ventricular function.

sentence.text: Concomitant use of catecholamine-depleting drugs, such as reserpine and guanethidine, with a beta-blocker may produce an excessive reduction of resting sympathetic nervous tone.

entity.text: excessive reduction of resting sympathetic nervous tone

mmtx.phraseText: an excessive reduction of resting sympathetic nervous tone.

sentence.text: Patients treated with Betapace plus a catecholamine depletor should therefore be closely monitored for evidence of hypotension and/or marked bradycardia which may produce syncope.
Insulin and oral antidiabetics
Hyperglycemia may occur, and the dosage of insulin or antidiabetic drugs may require adjustment.

ellipsisSentence.text: Patients treated with Betapace plus a catecholamine depletor should therefore be closely monitored for evidence of hypotension and/or marked bradycardia which may produce syncope.
Patients treated with Betapace plus a catecholamine depletor should therefore be closely monitored for evidence of hypotension and/or marked bradycardia which may produce syncope.

sentence.text: Beta-agonists such as salbutamol, terbutaline and isoprenaline may have to be administered in increased dosages when used concomitantly with Betapace.

Beta-blocking drugs may potentiate the rebound hypertension sometimes observed after discontinuation of clonidine, therefore, caution is advised when discontinuing clonidine in patients receiving Betapace.
No pharmacokinetic interactions were observed with hydrochlorothiazide or warfarin.

Administration of Betapace within 2 hours of antacids containing aluminum oxide and magnesium hydroxide should be avoided because it may result in a reduction in Cmax and AUC of 26% and 20%, respectively and consequently in a 25% reduction in the bradycardic effect at rest.

entity.text: antacids containing aluminum oxide and magnesium hydroxide
reduction in the bradycardic effect at rest

sentence.text: Administration of the antacid two hours after Betapace has no effect on the pharmacokinetics or pharmacodynamics of sotalol.

mmtx.phraseText: Administration of the antacid two hours

sentence.text: Betapace should be administered with caution in conjunction with other drugs known to prolong the QT interval such as Class I and Class III antiarrhythmic agents, phenothiazines, tricyclic antidepressants, astemizole, bepridil, certain oral macrolides, and certain quinolone antibiotics (see WARNINGS ).

entity.text: drugs known to prolong the QT interval
